Description: Neck of terracotta vessel. The upper fragment of a cylindrical stand, tapering from bottom to top. Below a slightly bulging panel with mouldings above and below, is the head of a maenad surmounting a vine-scroll. Her hair crosses her brow in curls, and falls from ties at each side, hanging in locks beside her face. The top scroll is tied in a bow below her chin. The back is plain. Hollow; two-piece mould. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt; traces of a white dressing, mainly on the front and surviving in substantial amounts within the hole at the top.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV Comparanda. Close and complete, probably from the same mould-series: Dunand 1990: no. 970, dated Roman period; at its base is the head of Seilenos or possibly Bes. The top part of Dunand 1990: no. 973, dated Roman period, is from an object close to ours, but it does not belong to the bottom part, which comes from a similar stand close to BM Terracotta 3273.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3275)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
